title: Japan trade deficit narrows in August on lower oil imports
content:
TOKYO — Japan reports its trade deficit narrowed in August as costs for crude oil imports plunged and exports to the U.S. showed steady growth.

The customs data released Thursday showed a 4.2 percent drop from August a year earlier in the volume of exports for the world's third-largest economy, likely mainly reflecting weakness in shipments to China.

But the value of exports rose 3.1 percent from a year earlier, while imports fell 3.1 percent. The 569.7 billion yen ($4.7 billion) deficit was the largest in seven months.

The slowdown in China's economy hit exports of steel, auto parts and metalworking machinery hardest. Exports to the U.S. rose 11 percent from a year earlier, mainly due to sales of cars and pharmaceuticals.
